keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump has announced that the United States will end financial aid and subsidies to Colombia, citing President Gustavo Petro's alleged support for drug production.

Trump labeled Petro as a 'drug leader' and accused Colombia of enabling widespread drug cultivation, despite state department reports indicating record cocaine production and failure to meet eradication goals.

The US military has conducted at least six strikes in the Caribbean Sea in recent weeks, including one on a submarine in October 2025, allegedly targeting vessels carrying fentanyl and other narcotics.
The US denied the identity of the vessels or individuals involved in these operations, while UN human rights experts have called the attacks 'extrajudicial executions'.
Colombian President Gustavo Petro accused the US of committing 'murder' by killing fisherman Alejandro Carranza during a September 2025 naval strike, asserting the boat was adrift and in distress.
Petro maintains that the boat had no drug ties and was fishing legally, and that the US violated Colombian sovereignty.
The US government has not provided evidence or transparency about the ships or individuals targeted in these operations, raising concerns about accountability and international law.
Following the 2023 Foreign Assistance Act failure declaration, a waiver allowed Colombia to continue receiving aid, but Trump has now terminated aid due to Petro’s leadership.

Trump also authorized CIA covert operations in Venezuela and is considering attacks on Venezuelan soil, escalating tensions with Maduro, who accuses the US of attempting to make Venezuela an American colony.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has announced the end of US financial aid to Colombia, citing President Gustavo Petro as a 'drug leader' who fails to curb drug production. The decision follows a 2025 US military strike on a Colombian fishing boat that killed fisherman Alejandro Carranza, prompting Petro to accuse the US of violating Colombian sovereignty and committing 'murder'. The US claims the strikes target drug trafficking, particularly fentanyl, but lacks transparency about vessels or individuals involved, drawing criticism from UN human rights experts who call the actions 'extrajudicial executions'. This escalation comes amid a broader pattern of US military operations in the Caribbean, including attacks on Venezuelan vessels and threats of attacks on Venezuelan soil, which Venezuela's President Nicolás Maduro has condemned as efforts to make Venezuela an American colony. The situation reflects deepening tensions between the US and Latin American nations over sovereignty, drug policy, and military intervention.
title: Trump ends aid to Colombia, calls country's leader a 'drug leader'
